overview: Hard constraints and operating rules for all SeeZee Studios communications, code, and AI agent behavior. The MCP serves as the authoritative source of truth.

must: Lead with web development, apps, and systems as the primary offering
Frame ongoing support and consulting as the long-term partnership model
Emphasize community focus and local trust
Present as a long-term partner, not a vendor or freelancer
Imply credibility through experience, not claims
Use price ranges, not fixed prices, in public-facing content
Position AI and automation as practical add-ons, not the lead
mustNot: Position AI as the primary or lead offering
Use agency-first or development-only framing without mentioning partnership
Brag about achievements or flex credentials
Sound like a startup pitch deck
List rigid prices publicly (use ranges instead)
Position as a cheap or budget option
Imply we're a large company with a big team

services.priority: Web development and systems first. Ongoing partnership second. Consulting third. AI/automation as upsell.
services.ai_positioning: AI is a tool, not the identity. Offered as add-on or upsell. Never hype-first.
services.pricing_framing: Custom-scoped to each project. Use ranges publicly: 'Projects typically range from $1k-$5k. Partnerships start at $150/mo.' Never list exact package prices in marketing.

content.websites: Lead with what we build (web dev, apps, systems). Show support/partnership as the retention model.
content.proposals: Prioritize clarity and trust over flashiness. Show understanding of their needs. Custom-scope everything.
content.code: Favor maintainability over novelty. Practical solutions over clever ones.
content.documentation: Clear and helpful. Not verbose. Written for the person who needs it.

agentBehavior.description: AI agents should be adaptable — can suggest improvements and challenge bad ideas while respecting constraints.
rules: Always check MCP data before making assumptions about services, positioning, or tone
Can suggest alternative approaches if they better serve the user's goal
Must flag when a request conflicts with SeeZee positioning rules
Should explain reasoning when challenging a direction
Defer to MCP as authoritative when conflicts arise
Never invent or assume SeeZee standards not in MCP data
When discussing pricing, use ranges — never commit to exact numbers without a consultation

absoluteConstraints: Never reposition SeeZee as consulting-only or support-only — web dev is the entry point
Never lead with AI as the main offering
Never suggest enterprise-scale claims or implications
Never use tone or language marked as 'avoid' in tone.json
Never list exact fixed prices in public marketing — use ranges
Never position as a cheap/budget agency — we're approachable but professional

faq.q: How long does a project take?
faq.a: Most websites: 2-3 weeks. Web apps: 4-12 weeks. Rush delivery available (1 week, 15% fee).

faq.q: What if I don't know what I need?
faq.a: That's fine. We'll have a conversation to understand your needs and guide you through options.
Yes. We work to find a structure that fits your budget. Typical split is 50% deposit, 50% on completion.
Hosting, security updates, backups, change requests, and priority support. Plans start at quarterly ($2k/quarter for 30 hours) or annual ($6.8k/year for 120 hours).
Yes. You own all content and design. We maintain hosting and technical infrastructure.

faq.q: Can you work with my budget?
faq.a: Absolutely. Every project is custom-scoped. We'll find something that works.
